thread.title: The three reasons why Theresa May's big conference speech was a disaster

author: Jonathan Walker
title: The three reasons why Theresa May's big conference speech was a disaster
text:
The three reasons why Theresa May's big conference speech was a disaster Interrupted by a heckler, coughing fits and the backdrop falling apart. Could it have been worse? Share   
Theresa May’s big speech to the Conservative Party conference was supposed to be a fresh start. 
She admitted the Conservative general election campaign had been a failure, saying: “I am sorry”. 
And she set out a series of major new policies, in an attempt to show her government was doing more than just Brexit. 
But it all went horribly wrong. 
First, the speech descended into chaos as a prankster handed her a P45 unemployment notice on stage. 
Comedian Lee Nelson - real name Simon Brodkin - joked that Foreign Secretary Boris Johnson had asked him to perform the stunt. 
Amid frantic scenes he was bundled out of the conference hall and through the exhibition stands by security staff at the Manchester Central venue. Comedian Simon Brodkin, also known as Lee Nelson confronts Prime Minister Theresa May during her keynote speech 
He told reporters: “Boris told me to do it. He’s left me in the lurch.” 
Then, Mrs May repeatedly had to stop talking because she had a series of coughing fits. 
The audience of Conservative activists broke into applause to try to give her a chance to recover. 
But it happened again and again. 
And then, the carefully-prepared backdrop behind her began to fall apart. 
White letters on a blue board spelt out the slogan: “Building A Country That Works For Everyone”. 
But the “F” fell off - so that it read “A Country That Works Or Everyone”. Read More 
And then other letters fell off too. 
One of these things would be bad enough on their own. 
For all these things to go wrong at once was a real disaster. 
The actual content of the speech wasn’t so bad. But when the moment came to deliver it, things could hardly have gone worse. 
Tory MPs rallied round. Hexham Conservative MP Guy Opperman said on Twitter: “Theresa May showed she is tough, resolute, full of duty and passionate for aspiration, free markets and a plan for a better Britain.” Like us on Facebook
